senses.de: To talk about something or someone in a few words
senses.ex: She mentioned that the store would be closed tomorrow.

Tips.title: Casual Conversation
Tips.description: Use 'mention' in informal chats to introduce a small piece of information.
Tips.example: Oh, I forgot to mention, we're having a party next week.

Tips.title: Brief Interjection
Tips.description: 'Mention' can introduce an aside or relevant fact while discussing something else.
Tips.example: The movie was great, not to mention the awesome soundtrack.

Tips.title: Avoid Overemphasis
Tips.description: Using 'mention' shows that the information is not the main focus of the conversation.
Tips.example: He briefly mentioned the meeting but didn't go into details.

senses.de: The act of talking about someone or something in a few words
senses.ex: I was surprised to hear a mention of my name in their conversation.

Tips.title: Subtle Recognition
Tips.description: A 'mention' can acknowledge someone's work or contribution without giving full focus.
Tips.example: She received an honorable mention for her artwork.

Tips.title: Limited Detail
Tips.description: A 'mention' implies that not much detail was provided about the topic or person.
Tips.example: They made a mention of the issue, but I wish they had elaborated.

senses.de: To say or write something in a formal or official way
senses.ex: The report did not mention any names.

Tips.title: Formal Reference
Tips.description: In academic or official contexts, 'mention' means to acknowledge something with authority.
Tips.example: The textbook mentions Piaget's theory in chapter three.

Tips.title: Official Documentation
Tips.description: Use 'mention' to refer to something that needs to be recognized in a formal document.
Tips.example: The contract mentions the confidentiality clause on page five.

senses.de: A reference or citation in a document
senses.ex: The research paper had several mentions of previous studies on the topic.

Tips.title: Academic Citations
Tips.description: 'Mention' is used for citing sources in scholarly works, showing respect for prior research.
Tips.example: His paper mentioned several key studies that supported his hypothesis.

Tips.title: Crediting Sources
Tips.description: Mentioning work in academic papers shows the breadth of research done.
Tips.example: Throughout her thesis, she mentioned various authors who influenced her theory.

Allude to.wordDefinition:
The words allude to and mention have different meanings. Mention means to directly refer to something or someone. For example, "I mentioned to my friend about the movie I saw last night.".

Allude to means to refer to something indirectly, without actually saying it outright. For example, "She alluded to her ex-boyfriend without directly talking about him.".

Each one is applicable in different situations. Use mention when you want to directly refer to something or someone, while use allude to when you want to refer to something indirectly.

Bring up.wordDefinition:
The phrase bring up means to introduce a topic or subject for discussion, while mention means to briefly refer to something without going into detail.

For example, you might bring up a new movie you want to see with your friends as a possible activity, but only briefly mention it in passing if you're talking about something else.

Bring up is applicable when you want to start a conversation about a specific topic, while mention is more appropriate when you want to give a quick reference to something without discussing it in depth.

Cite.wordDefinition:
Cite refers to giving credit to a source for a fact or idea used in a piece of work. For example, when writing an essay, you would cite the sources you used for quotations or statistics.

Mention means to briefly refer to something in a piece of work without necessarily giving credit to a source. For example, if you were writing a personal narrative, you might mention a place you visited without citing a specific source.

Cite is used to give credit to sources, while mention is used to briefly refer to something without necessarily giving credit.

Introduce.wordDefinition:
Introduce means to make someone aware of someone or something for the first time. It is mostly used when you are presenting someone to a group of people or when you are formally presenting an idea or concept.

For example, "May I introduce you to my friend Sarah?" or "I would like to introduce the concept of sustainability."

Name.wordDefinition:
Name refers to identifying a specific person, place, or thing by their given title or label. It's like pointing out something in a conversation by giving it an exact name.

For example: "She named her dog Spot."

To put it simply, mention is used to bring up a topic in passing, while name is used to give something or someone a specific title or identity.

Note.wordDefinition:
Note means to record or take notice of something important.

It is used when something needs to be recorded for future reference or when it is particularly important to remember. For example, "I noted down the important points from the meeting.".

Mention is used when something is briefly brought up or spoken about, while note is used when something needs to be recorded or remembered for future reference or when it is particularly important.

Quote.wordDefinition: Quote means to precisely repeat or reproduce someone's exact words or phrases. It is applicable when you want to provide a verbatim representation of someone's statement or text.

Refer to.wordDefinition:
Mention means to briefly bring up or talk about something without going into much detail. It's often used when introducing a topic or idea, or when discussing something in passing.

Refer to means to direct someone's attention to something else that might help explain or clarify what is being talked about.

It's often used when there is a need to go into more detail about a particular topic or idea.

For example, if you were talking about a book you read, you might mention the title and author. But if you wanted to discuss a specific passage or quote from the book, you might refer to that particular section to provide more context.

Mention is used when you want to bring something up quickly or briefly, while refer to is used when you want to provide more information or context about something.

Remark.wordDefinition:
Remark means to comment on or express an opinion about something, often in a more detailed manner. It is applicable when you want to give your thoughts or opinions on a particular topic or issue.

In simpler terms, to mention is to bring something up briefly, while to remark is to say more about it.
